questions.prompt: In which English county is the monument of Stonehenge located?
questions.explanation: The ancestors of the first farmers probably came from south-east Europe. These people built houses, tombs and monuments on the land. One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire.

questions.prompt: What is the best-known work from Robert Burns?
questions.explanation: Burns’ best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.prompt: Which of the following crosses does NOT form part of the Union Flag?
options: The cross of St George, patron saint of England
The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland
The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland
questions.explanation: The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales does not form part of the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.prompt: What day is Halloween celebrated?
questions.explanation: Halloween is celebrated on the 31st of October.

questions.prompt: Who was the first British distance runner to win a gold medal in the Olympic games in the 10,000 metres?
questions.explanation: Mo Farah (1983-) is a British distance runner, born in Somalia. He won gold medals in the 2012 Olympics for the 5,000 and 10,000 metres and is the first Briton to win the Olympic gold medal in the 10,000 metres.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: For some Scottish people, Hogmanay is a bigger holiday than Christmas
For some Scottish people, Hogmanay is a bigger holiday than New Year’s Eve
For some Welsh people, Hogmanay is a bigger holiday than Christmas
For some Irish people, Hogmanay is a bigger holiday than New Year’s Eve
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the 31st December is called Hogmanay and 2 January is also a public holiday. For some Scottish people, Hogmanay is a bigger holiday than Christmas.

questions.prompt: Light-hearted plays with music and comedy, which are enjoyed by family audiences and based on fairy stories are known as:
questions.explanation: Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences.

questions.prompt: What British actor was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays?
questions.explanation: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director, best actor and best actress. The awards are named after the British actor Sir Laurence Olivier, late Lord Olivier, who was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays.

questions.prompt: Who built the Tower of London after becoming king in 1066?
questions.explanation: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

questions.prompt: Who succeeded David Cameron as Prime Minister after the referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union?
questions.explanation: David Cameron was succeeded as Prime Minister after the Brexit referendum by Theresa May on 13 July 2016.

questions.prompt: Who composed a suite of pieces themed around the planets and the solar system called ‘The Planets’?
questions.explanation: Important British composers include Gustav Holst, whose work includes The Planets, a suite of pieces themed around the planets and the solar system.

questions.prompt: What was the population of the UK in 1998?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK in 1998 was 57 million people.

questions.prompt: Who is the chief officer of the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief officer of the House of Commons.

questions.prompt: What characterises the British constitution?
options: It was written by the Prime Minister
It was written by the King
It is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten
It was written by Henry VIII
questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’.

questions.prompt: How old was Queen Victoria when she became Queen in 1837?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18.

questions.prompt: When did the First World War start?
questions.explanation: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War (1914-18).

questions.prompt: Who forms the judiciary?
questions.explanation: Judges (who are together called ‘the judiciary’) are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a musical venue located in London?
questions.explanation: There are many large venues that host music events throughout the year, such as: The O2 in Greenwich, south-east London.

questions.prompt: Who directed the movie ‘The Killing Fields’ in 1984?
questions.explanation: The Killing Fields (1984) was directed by Roland Joffé.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following castles are located in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Inveraray Castle and Crathes Castle are located in Scotland.

questions.prompt: Which battle signified the end of the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

questions.prompt: Which court deals with minor criminal offences in Scotland?
options: The Justice of the Peace Court
questions.explanation: In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.prompt: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, which is known as:
questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

questions.prompt: A person who has not paid enough National Insurance contributions will not be able to receive certain contributory benefits including (choose TWO options):
questions.explanation: Anyone who does not pay enough National Insurance Contributions will not be able to receive certain contributory benefits such as Jobseeker’s Allowance or a full state retirement pension.
